Compress air in the Right Compressor…
and hold the lever down 1..2..3.. Let go.
· Watch the Air Pressure gauge
· Look at the red area in the
Air Pressure vs Air Volume graph
· Repeat and watch the Air Temperature thermometer
Notice the air pressure doesn’t rise as high in the Heat-Recovery Compressor, but it also doesn’t fall as far.
What’s happening?
Find the heat sink. Water droplets on the screen store a lot of the heat that without the heat sink would raise the temperature of the air inside the cylinder. Lower air temperature means less back pressure — it’s easier for you to move the piston. Expanding the air recovers the lost heat.
Smaller heat loss means less work wasted.

Notice this:
The area between the two
curves curves—the record of your
work—on the Right Graph is smaller than
this area on the Left Graph.
What’s happening?
The heat-trapping screen
nested in the Right Compressor recycles the
heat you generate, resulting in less wasted
work.
So what?
This experiment shows promise
for heat-recycling research underway at the
University of Minnesota’s Center for
Compact and Efficient Fluid Power.
